awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: An Entropy Framework for Communications and Dynamics Interdependency in Cyber Physical Systems: Analysis, Design and Implementation
awd_abstract_narration:
Many practical systems such as smart grid, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and robotic networks can be categorized as cyber physical systems (CPS). A typical CPS consists of physical dynamics, sensors, communication network and controllers. The communication network is of key importance in CPS, since it mimics the nerve system in the human body. Hence, it is critical to study how the communication network in CPS should be analyzed and designed. Essentially, communications stem from the uncertainty of system under consideration; random perturbations increase the system uncertainty, which is reduced by the control actions in CPS. It is well known that entropy is a measure of system uncertainty. A unified framework of entropy is used for CPS, in which random perturbations create entropy while communications and controls provide negative entropy to compensate the entropy generation. The intellectual merits are the novel framework of entropy for bridging the communications and control in CPS and the new design criterion based on the entropy of system state for CPS. The project's broader significance and importance are the education of various levels of students, the dissemination of results to public, and the impact on everyday life such as the improved agility and robustness of power grids.

This project applies the framework of entropy to study the interdependencies of communications and control, thus facilitating the analysis and design of communications in CPS. The following tasks are tackled in the project: (a) Entropy Flow Based Communication Capacity Analysis in which communications in CPS is analyzed by studying the entropy fields in the physical dynamics, thus providing an estimation on the scale (bits/second) of communication capacity budget; (b) Communication Network Topology Design in which the design of the network topology (either physical or logical) is tackled through both optimization-based or heuristic approaches; (c) Online Network Resource Scheduling which refines the network resource scheduling during the operation using both optimization-based and heuristic approaches, within the framework of entropy fields; (d) Hardware Emulation Testbed which delivers a co-simulation testbed based on real time digital power simulator (RTDS) and a communication simulator, in the context of smart grids. Based on the research, new courses are developed. K-12 outreach and various levels of undergraduate/graduate educations are incorporated into the research.

por.por_cntn:
In the last decade, there have been substantial studies on cyber physical systems (CPSs). A typical CPS consists of both physical and cyber components. The physical component usually follows dynamics ruled by physics laws, while the cyber part (which includes sensors, communication networks and controllers) measures, communicates and controls the physical dynamics. Many practical systems can be categorized as CPS, such as smart grids, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and robotic networks. The communication network is of key importance in CPS, since it mimics the nerve system in the human body. For example, in smart grid, a wide area monitoring system (WAMS) can send various measurements from sensors (often called phasor measurement units (PMUs) to control center(s). The project proposed a unified framework of entropy for modeling the interdependency of communications and dynamical systems and designing the corresponding communication capacity, network topology and scheduling policies. Entropy is a crtical concept in physics and inforatmion theory, which characterizes the uncertainty and randomness iin various events. This framework is motivated by the fact that communications arise from randomness and uncertainty which can be measured by information entropy. On the other hand, according to the second law of thermodynamics, the entropy of an isolated system cannot decrease spontaneously; therefore, negative entropy from external sources (e.g., sensors) is needed to reduce the entropy. Hence, on one hand, positive entropy in the physical dynamics is generated by random perturbations (e.g., load variations in power grids); on the other hand, the entropy is (partially) compensated by the `negative entropy' provided by communications. Hence, the communications and dynamical systems are coupled by the concept of entropy. The PI will study how the entropy is generated by random perturbations, propagated in the network of physical nodes, and decimated by the information provided by the communication network. In the case of networked CPSs, the entropies of different physical nodes form a field and could form a wave in nonstationary cases, in which the positive entropies of physical nodes and negative entropies brought by communication nodes trigger and impact each other. In the project, the PI has proved that, given mild conditions, the information conveyed through the communication network is no more than the enropy reduction in the physical dynamics. Moreover, the entropy propagation in networks of CPS modes is similar to water waves, but not being conserved. The validity of the entropy framework has been demonstrated in the project.
